metadata.feature_description: Caching mechanism for analytics data to improve performance

steps.action: Login to DNN as host user and navigate to Dashboard > Community Analytics
steps.expected: Community Analytics dashboard should load with analytics data
steps.actual: Community Analytics dashboard loaded successfully showing analytics for Answers, Blogs, Discussions, Events, Ideas, and Wiki modules with Community Health metrics, Engagement charts, and Creates & Views data

steps.action: Change the Comparative Term from '1 w' to '1 m' in the dropdown
steps.expected: Dashboard should refresh with new comparative term data
steps.actual: Dashboard successfully refreshed when comparative term was changed to '1 m', demonstrating that the API endpoints (GetModuleDashboardInfo) are responding correctly for different query parameters

observations: CRITICAL: The 'Analytics Data Caching' feature has NO caching implementation in the CommunityAnalytics module codebase. The Services/CommunityAnalyticsController.cs simply delegates calls to IAnalyticsController (from DotNetNuke.SocialLibrary.Components.Controllers) without any caching logic.

The suggested test scenarios (cache initialization, cache expiration, cache invalidation, concurrent access, cache hit rates, cache size limits) are ALL backend/internal behaviors that cannot be tested via UI.
If any caching exists, it is implemented in the external DotNetNuke.SocialLibrary dependency which is not part of this repository.
There are NO UI elements for cache management - no cache settings, status indicators, hit rate displays, or cache invalidation controls visible in the Community Analytics interface.

Network analysis confirmed that API calls to /API/personabar/CommunityAnalytics/GetModuleDashboardInfo are made successfully (HTTP 200 OK) for each module (Answers, Blogs, Discussions, Social Events, Ideas, Wiki). Any caching would occur at the server level and is not observable from the client.
The feature description states 'UI Location: Backend Service' which confirms this is an internal server-side optimization not intended for direct UI testing.
Per testing guidelines: Features that exist in code but have no visible UI elements should not have test scenarios created for them. This observation documents the feature's backend nature.
